answers.author: Alexandra Iannolo
answers.text:
Hello,
To help answer your question, you can use the following links which go to the private activity bond website pages of Missouri and Iowa. They both include general information about the bond process in addition to possible allocation and application forms.
1-Missouri http://www.missouridevelopment.org/topnavpages/research%20toolbox/bcs%20programs/Private%20Activity%20Bond%20Allocation%20Tax%20Exempt%20Bond%20Cap.html
2- Iowa
http://www.iowafinanceauthority.gov/en/economic_development/private_activity_bond_cap_allocation/
I also located meeting documents from, Washoe County, Nevada and the City of Urbana, Illinois about bond cap transfers. Both documents include an example transfer resolution at the bottom of the meeting notes.
1-Washoe County, Nevada 
http://www.co.washoe.nv.us/large_files/agendas/082206/23.pdf
2- City of Urbana, Illinois
http://urbanaillinois.us/sites/default/files/attachments/resolution-2011-04-012r.pdf
To find more information on this issue you can use the Council of Development Finance Agency’s page on private activity bond caps. It has studies and information on different bond cap policies nationwide.
http://www.cdfa.net/cdfa/cdfaweb.nsf/ord.html?open&tag=Bond%20Volume%20Cap&start=26&count=25
I hope these help.
Ali Iannolo
ICMA Knowledge Network Intern
aiannolo@ICMA.org

author: Lisa Granahan
text: I'm looking for a policy or annual process in place to determine a priority for the transfer of your Private Activity Bond Cap.  Douglas County has transferred its cap to the Nevada Rural Hosing Authority in past years, but is now interested in determining the priority for this year's transfer (e.g. creation of jobs vs. affordable housing).   If you have transferred bond cap to private industry, I'm also interested in what forms/applications you have used.
title: Policy related to the transfer of Private Activity Bond Cap
